title: Is VP Mike Pence terrified of President Trump? - Quora
tags: Vice President of the United States
Donald Trump Picks Mike Pence as Running Mate (July 2016)
Presidents of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Cowed would be a better word than terrified. Pence had won a tight race as governor in 2012 and had low approval numbers coming into his 2016 reelection campaign. His policies based on very conservative Christian ideology had been criticised by many. Given that he accepted to become Trump’s running mate Trump was the underdog and in many ways was very much against the values Pence claimed. So he must have felt his reelection prospects were pretty bad. His gamble paid off and Pence seems to have played the perfect Trump VP so far, discreet and almost fawning. Unlike cabinet positions with actual power Pence is less likely to have to contradict or oppose Trump so his position is more secure than the others’. So what does he have to fear? Unlike appointees Pence can’t be fired so his position is secure until January 2021. The worst possibility is that Trump might want a new running mate. And if he does Pence political career may well be over. The primaries are over and there is no open race for him to enter so late in the election cycle. A senate election will occur in Indiana in 2022 but he’ll have to oust incumbent fellow Republican Toss Young unless the latter decides not to run for that position again. All other options available that year would be a step down for Pence. And by 2024 he probably will have been forgotten. He doesn’t have a lot of charisma so he would have difficulty staying in the public eye for four years like Sarah Palin, despite all her flaws, managed to. Even Trump supporters are unlikely to feel enthusiastic about him. Those love Trump’s brashness and offensiveness. And anyway they are from a dwindling demographic. And to the rest of voters he’ll carry the stench of his association with Trump. All his hopes rest on staying as running mate and Trump winning again. I see no other bright future for him. And while there is talk of Trump changing mate he might find it difficult to find someone better than Pence. If you’re an up and coming politician who wants to use the vice-presidency as a stepping stone. Trump has been very divisive and good VP candidates might be hesitant, especially given how difficult working with Trump has been shown to be. And if you want visibility through a stint as VP there’s the fact that Trump doesn’t share the limelight.

No. Pence is Trump’s handler. If anything Trump fears Pence. It wasn’t until Trump named Pence his running mate that the party (enough at least) went all in on Trump. You may notice Trump changing his tune a little bit once Pence came aboard. E.g. Trump began using terrorism as a bigger talking point. Trump eased off his trash talk of anyone in the Bush family. (Remember he accused Bush of lying about WMDs and knowing about 9/11 beforehand? Wow! You’ll never hear Trump say that again.) Trump going “off the rails” imho can feel a little scripted. But Pence is the guy who accused John Ashcroft of being a terrorist for disputing Pence’s claim (which Pence knew was a lie) that Saddam Hussein was sending “super anthrax” to the USA after 9/11. Yeah, remember anthrax? Mike Pence was on the anthrax task force. Funny how they never mention that as a qualification for being on the 2020 task force, isn’t it.
